title: 108_hr2539
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Violence Against Children Act of 2003". Congress finds that people under 18 account for 12% of crime victims, with high percentages in sex crimes and kidnappings. Those aged 12-17 are over 2 times more likely to be victims of violent crime than adults. Only 28% of crimes against children are reported, with 1,200 child abuse deaths annually and 879,000 abuse victims. Child abuse has long-lasting negative effects on children and families, including delayed development, depression, substance abuse, and increased likelihood of experiencing or perpetrating domestic violence as an adult. Most local agencies lack resources to protect children and families adequately. Failure to pay child support is a form of neglect, leading to children living in poverty and facing inadequate education and health. Children living in poverty often suffer from inadequate education, lack of quality health care, and affordable housing. TITLE I--ENHANCED FEDERAL ROLE IN CRIMES AGAINST CHILDREN

SEC. 101. ENHANCED PENALTIES. Chapter 110 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include a new section on violence against children. It states that anyone who willfully injures a person under 18 years of age by force or threat of force can face imprisonment for up to 10 years and fines. If death results from the offense, the perpetrator can be imprisoned for any term of years or for life. The new section on violence against children in Chapter 110 of title 18, United States Code, includes provisions for imprisonment and fines for those who injure minors. If death results from the offense or if the offense involves specific crimes like kidnapping or sexual abuse, harsher penalties apply. The circumstances for these penalties include the offense occurring during travel across state lines or national borders. The new section in Chapter 110 of title 18, United States Code, addresses violence against children. It includes penalties for using interstate commerce or weapons in connection with the offense. Offenses under this section are subject to penalties in section 1111 of the title. The new section in Chapter 110 of title 18, United States Code, addresses violence against children with enhanced penalties for crimes committed against children under the age of 18. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and amend guidelines for these cases. Additionally, the Comptroller General of the United States will review state laws related to crimes against children within 6 months of the Act's enactment. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and amend guidelines for crimes against children under 18, including enhanced penalties. The Comptroller General of the United States will review state laws related to crimes against children and report findings to Congress. SEC. 102. ENHANCED ASSISTANCE FOR CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS AND PROSECUTIONS BY STATE AND LOCAL LAW ENFORCEMENT OFFICIALS. The Attorney General shall provide assistance in criminal investigations or prosecutions of violent crimes against minors at the request of a State, Indian tribal government, or local government. If resources are insufficient, priority will be given to fulfilling these requests. The Attorney General prioritizes requests for assistance in criminal investigations or prosecutions involving offenders who have committed crimes in multiple states and rural jurisdictions facing financial challenges. TITLE II--GRANT PROGRAMS

SEC. 201. FEDERAL ASSISTANCE TO STATE AND LOCAL LAW ENFORCEMENT. The Attorney General awards grants to assist in law enforcement and prosecution of crimes against children, providing personnel, training, and equipment for apprehension and adjudication of offenders. Training is focused on improving identification and response to crimes against children by law enforcement officers, prosecutors, judges, and court personnel. The Attorney General awards grants to assist in law enforcement and prosecution of crimes against children, focusing on developing specialized units and implementing effective policies and data systems to prevent, identify, and respond to these crimes. The Attorney General awards grants to assist in law enforcement and prosecution of crimes against children, focusing on identifying and tracking arrests, prosecutions, and convictions for crimes against children, enhancing collaboration between law enforcement and child services agencies, and addressing the needs of Indian tribes in dealing with crimes against children. Each State, Indian tribal government, or local government seeking a grant under this section must submit an application to the Attorney General with necessary information. The application should outline the reasons for needing the grant. To apply for a grant under this section, the State, Indian tribal government, or local government must provide details on the intended use of funds, expected results, consultation with victim services programs, and certification of compliance. The State, Indian tribal government, or local government must certify that federal funds will supplement, not supplant, non-federal funds and comply with sections 301 and 302. $25,000,000 is authorized for this section. $25,000,000 appropriated annually for fiscal years 2004-2008 to carry out this section. SEC. 202. EDUCATION, PREVENTION, AND VICTIMS' ASSISTANCE GRANTS. The Attorney General awards grants to assist in providing education, prevention, intervention, and victims' assistance services for crimes against children. Grants are used for educational seminars, hotlines, and training programs for professionals. The Attorney General awards grants for various services to prevent and address crimes against children, including hotlines, training programs, informational materials, intervention services, emergency medical treatment, counseling, and increasing mental health professionals. The Attorney General awards grants for services to prevent and address crimes against children, including increasing the supply of mental health professionals specializing in the mental health of victims. States, tribal governments, local governments, or organizations must submit an application to the Attorney General to receive a grant, meeting specific requirements. Applicants for grants must describe the purposes, intended use, and expected results of the grant funds. They must also demonstrate a plan for implementing the grant. Applicants for grants must show consultation with victim services programs experienced in helping children and demonstrate experience in providing education, prevention, or intervention services. Applicants for grants must demonstrate experience in providing education, prevention, or intervention services for crimes against children and certify that federal funds will supplement, not supplant, non-federal funds for these activities. The General may waive requirements for nongovernmental organizations in exceptional circumstances, as long as the State or tribal government is in compliance with section 303. Authorization of appropriations is provided. Authorization of Appropriations: $25,000,000 authorized for each fiscal year from 2004 to 2008. TITLE III--NATIONWIDE PROGRAMS

SEC. 301. NATIONWIDE AMBER ALERT.

Each State receiving grants must establish a statewide AMBER Alert network for child abduction cases within 3 years.

SEC. 302. IMPROVED STATISTICAL GATHERING.

States must use or develop protocols to use the National Incident-Based Reporting System.

SEC. 303. NATIONAL SAFE HAVEN. Each State receiving grants under this Act must have a statute allowing parents to leave a newborn with a hospital employee anonymously without penalty, collect family medical history with parent approval, and involve law enforcement after child relinquishment. The State must search missing person databases after a child is relinquished and publicize the Safe Haven law. An exception allows a State to deny anonymity if a newborn shows signs of abuse. SEC. 304. IMPROVED CHILD PROTECTION SERVICES PROGRAMS. States must submit a report on their child welfare services program within 180 days of receiving funding, detailing record-keeping and child well-being verification processes. The General Accounting Office will also report to Congress on State practices and policies in the child welfare program. The report on the child welfare program funded under subpart 1 of part B of title IV of the Social Security Act must include how States maintain records and verify the well-being of children in their care, the impact of the review system by the Secretary of Health and Human Services on State reforms, best practices implemented by States, and recommendations for legislative changes by Congress. SENSE OF THE SENATE ON TAX TREATMENT OF CHILD SUPPORT: Congress should pass legislation to extend Federal tax treatment on nonpayment of child support by allowing deductions for unpaid amounts and requiring unpaid child support to be added to income for tax purposes.
